prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ID 141 - [NII] 122 micron line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will map the [NII] 122 micron line in ID 141

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator setup: We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the [NII] velocity components of our sources, obtain a good measure of the baseline, and allow for sensitive simultaneous mapping of the 122 µm continuum. For this Band 8 science goal we use three basebands operating in 2000 MHz mode. We will post process the data to give a final spectrum with the desired 150 km/s. The three basebands are overlapped about ~150 MHz to ensure good coverage of the entire sideband, and to ensure all three basebands can be fit in one sideband.
Imaging Requirements: We require no special imaging techniques. We will observe the source in the compact configuration, which provides adequate field of view and angular resolution for our proposed observations and science. In order to achieve our desired SNR for our line, we may UV taper or spatially bin our observations to a 1” beam, slight larger than the synthesized beam in the compact configuration.
Requested Sensitivity: We require at least a 5σ detection of the [NII] line. To achieve this, we have balanced the other observing parameters – beam size and spectral resolution – such that this sensitivity is achievable from this source in no more than few hours of observations. Our method for determining the expected line fluxes is discussed in the the science justification as is a summary of our required sensitivities and integration times.

For this Band 9 science goal we use 4 basebands operating in 2000 MHz mode. We will post process the data to give a final spectrum with the desired 150 km/s. The three basebands are overlapped about ~150 MHz to ensure good coverage of the entire sideband, and to ensure all three basebands can be fit in one sideband.

To achieve this, we have balanced the other observing parameters – beam size and spectral resolution – such that this sensitivity is achievable from this source in no more than few hours of observations. Our method for determining the expected line fluxes is discussed in the the science justification as is a summary of our required sensitivities and integration times.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BRI 0952 - [OIII] 88 micron line

Correlator setup: We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the [OIII] velocity components of our sources, obtain a good measure of the baseline, and allow for sensitive simultaneous mapping of the 88 µm continuum. For this Band 9 science goal we use 4 basebands operating in 2000 MHz mode. We will post process the data to give a final spectrum with the desired 150 km/s. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The far-infrared fine structure lines are powerful probes of the physical conditions of the ISM. We propose to use the unparalleled sensitivity and resolution of ALMA to perform the first survey of the [OIII] 88 µm and [NII] 122 µm lines at high-z. Previously we made the first high-z study of the line ratio as reported in Ferkinhoff et al. (2011), in which we demonstrate the utility of these lines for understanding conditions inside a galaxy at high redshift. An ALMA Early Science program successfully mapped the [NII] line in this same galaxy. Our proposed survey we will map both the [OIII] and [NII] lines in two quasar host galaxies (BRI 1335 – 0417 and BRI 0952 – 0115) and a lensed submillimeter galaxy at z~4.4, requiring 8.3 and 10.3 hours of Band 9 and 8 observations respectively. These observations will allow us to search for evolutionary links between AGN and star formation, determine if our sources have a top-heavy stellar IMF, and verify that the relation between star-formation-rate surface-density and ionized-gas mass extends to higher redshifts. These results will reveal import new details on the characteristics, formation, and evolution of galaxies at high-z.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
